022861.question: Hi, I was the one who asked about Ryland by Julian Lage (on World's Fair). There are really quiet notes in the first and second measures of the song (if you are thinking of it in 6/8) starting on the sixth 8th note that goes A D A D A. And the next time it happens is on the down beat of the 4th measure and the notes are G E G E. There are other times it happens with different notes too. My first guess was that they were harmonics because some of them seem out of tune but I can't figure it out.
022861.answer: i'm hearing different ones than you are mentioning, like the one that comes out most prominently is the top of bar 2 (in 6/8) there is a loud F note (out of key). this is a hammer-on, from the wrong half of the string. this only happens acoustically, and it happens worse when you are playing in the middle of the string (or in the high fret range). if you do a hammer-on, it vibrates the correct half of the string (which gives you the note you want) but also the back half of the string (to the left of your left hand). on electric, you usually wouldn't hear it. but unplugged, the 2 notes will be of equal volume if the note is near the middle of the string. so in this case it is exactly in the middle of the string (12th fret) so both sides resonate equally. on a fretless instrument i think this would be the same note, but because it's fretted instrument, the target point to press is actually on the right bar of the fret, not the left. but the reverse note is happening from the other side, from the bar on the left side of the fret. so it's a slightly shorter distance. so you'll get F instead of E. this is not the note that you mentioned, but it seems to be the loudest and most obvious one right from the very beginning. the reason it is particularly problematic is because he's hitting it harder, for groove's sake, since it's the downbeat of the bar. really to avoid this in an acoustic close-mic situation is you have to try not to hammer as hard with the left hand, and do more of the work with your right hand. the rest of the quiet out-of-tune notes i believe are also unwanted reverse hammer-ons, but as we get closer to the left (the head? neck? sorry don't really know guitar terms, i am not a guitar player) the reverse hammer-on would be quieter, and higher. wherever you do a hammer-on, the lower (longer) of the 2 notes will be louder. that's just my analysis. i'm not really a guitar player

022867.question: I am looking at a piece of sheet music and it has 2 sets of quintuplet 16th notes, and a set of sextuplet 16th notes, all noted together as a triplet.. like there's 2 sets of 5 sixteenth notes with the little bracket and a 5 over each group, and then six sixteenth notes with a little bracket and a 6, and then over all 3 groups there's one long bracket with a 3... what is this mean? Ive never seen a tuplet inside of a tuplet before... How am I supposed to play that?
022867.answer: tuplets actually have a hidden number. any time you see the "3" for triplet, it's actually shorthand for "3:2" which means '3 notes in the time there would normally be 2 of these.' when 5's and 6's are used, it can be ambiguous whether it means 5:2 or 5:4, but regardless it is easy to figure out by looking at the context. but the time under the triplet bracket should be divided in 3, and then each of those thirds divided into 5, 5, and 6. or, for a reasonable human, just play 16 (oh wow, just realized the strange implications of this) notes in that time .... So really all this is saying is, play it like 32nd notes (or 16ths, depending on whether the triplet bracket takes up a whole bar or half a bar, that you can discern by looking at what else is in the bar)... so yeah basically the only technical difference between this and 32nd notes is basically they are just asking you to play the first 10 notes slower by an extremely negligible and unnoticeable amount. unless of course the rest of the music is in triplets anyway, in which case it would be normal to divide it in 3's. a lot of questions here that the context will answer. such as the tempo, and what the notes are

022900.question: Hey, I asked the question about that 5,5,6 triplet thing! So, the song is in 4/4 time (slower tempo, about 80bpm). The full measure is a dotted eighth, then a sixteenth note tied to a quarter note, then that 5,5,6, triplet thing. So that 5,5,6 triplet should take up 2 beats. So, it's like dividing 2 beats into 3 equal parts (3:2 quarter note triplet), then taking those 3 equal parts and dividing them again into 5,5, and 6 respectively? This piece also has several septuplets and pentuplets and all that kind of stuff... In general, what are some good ways to figure out how to hear/play this kind of timing? I can conceptualize it, and I think I understand how it works. But the challenge is like, okay, so how do I actually play 7 equally spaced hits over the span of 2 beats, or whatever? I can play 3:2 1/4, 1/8, 1/16 note triplets because I hear them used all the time, and can just play it without actually counting it out, i just know how it sounds.. Is it possi ble to be able to sight read these kind of weird tuplets/polyrhythms? Or is it something that you just have to hear each particular rhythm over and over again until it sinks in?
022900.answer: so basically if you just played this as 32nd notes, no one would ever know the difference. we're talking about squeezing 16 notes into 2 beats at 80bpm. grouping it evenly in thirds as 5+5+6 is not really going to be distinguishible from even 16, from the listener's or player's perspective. i would ask the composer what the point was of writing it that way, and maybe they could give you some insight as to how it's played. sometimes composers like to showoff on the page how many crazy looking numbers they can put in, now i'm not suggesting that this composer would do such a thing! but it's worth a thought you could think of it as 4 sixteenth notes and 3 triplets, but slow it down a little bit so the middle click is halfway in between your 4th and 5th note no matter what year you live in or what country you go to, these types of complex mathematical exercises will be used in less than 1% of music. most often when complex number tuplets are used, (5, 7, etc) it is really only an approximation of something else, more musical perhaps. always check with the director or composer because they might be able to describe what they are looking for

023015.question: why is the circle of 5ths important? why not the circle of 3rds?

023024.question: Is "super chorus" a term you created, or is it a term that all music people are taught?
023024.answer: i made it up. it was inspired by popular music of the past few years. it can be found elsewhere too, but i noticed it seems to be very standard in the past 5 years or so. you have the 'chorus' which feels like the chorus, and has a lot of words in it. but then the next section hits even harder and is usually just one word/phrase (usually just the title) repeated in a climactic riff. maybe not even the word, maybe just a climactic riff. and this happens even after the first chorus. it is built into the form. chorus, then super-chorus. it's like more chorus than the chorus

023064.question: Hi Bill! I'm learning piano, and I really love that funky synth sound. But sometimes I have hard time figuring out certain chords I hear (maybe cause the notes of a chord played on a synth blend together more than a piano chord?)... But I was wondering if you can help me out with this. In this song, could you tell me the voicing for the chord that plays around the 1:44 right after 'just can't wait no more'? Also those little chord hits that play around 2:44 right after 'baby I'm sure you would'? Here's the song. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LVSfnXeYmtQ
023064.answer: that's a closed Bmin7 voicing, but it might likely have been played as Amin7 and bent up, depending on whether the player prefers to pull down the bender first and bend up to the chord, or play the chord first lower and then raise the bender. so you could play G,A,C,E, and bend it up, or pull back the bender first and play A,B,D,F# and then bend it back to center. also important to mention that this tape is also running just a hair sharp Amin6. very densely, possibly doubled in octaves, because there is definitely high A (880), but the F#(the 6 note) seems to be coming from more than an octave below. and in between you surely would have your C and E. it's just really dense and thick. also drenched in vibrato. it's Amin6, which means it includes notes A, C, E, F#. intuition tells me that this sound is automatically doubled an octave, and it's a one handed 5-note voicing with A on both ends. left hand would be working the bender/vibrato wheels

023083.question: Hello, I am interested in learning music. I know the notes and octaves and staffs and voice ranges. But I don't know what exactly a chord is. And how are they played? When do you use them? And what is the difference between flats and sharps? When are they used? If you can, please tell me. Thank you so much!
023083.answer: a chord is multiple notes at the same time. listen to any recorded song, and there is probably a 99% chance it has chords in it, unless it is just a singer with no accompaniment. how exactly to use them, well, i don't think there is any accurate way to explain it, but you can learn everything you ever need to know from experimentation. i'll give you a hint to get started, playing notes C, E, and G at the same time is called a C major chord, or often just called C. that should be more than enough to get started

023084.question: is it the question mark or the fact that something is being asked make a normal sentence into a question?
023084.answer: in many languages and dialects (including the one you used in your question) 2 of the core words sometimes switch places when it's a question. but also an important factor is the plausibility that the thing is actually in question. additionally, if there is no question mark nor word reversal, often the presence of the word 'really/seriously/actually' can imply the question, if it is in conjunction with something that would plausibly be a question, in the context

023122.question: You answered a question recently saying that there's a circles of thirds(if I'm wrong I'm sorry) anyway, are there circles for every distance interval thing? Like is there a circle of 6ths? Circle of 4ths? 2nds? 7ths? That'd be cool if that's true.
023122.answer: sure, you could think of it that way. any interval when stacked will eventually get back to the same note. 4ths are just reversed 5ths, so the circle of 4ths is really the same as the circle of 5ths. 6ths and 3rds are the reverse of each other if you flip the major/minor, so everything i said about major/minor thirds would basically be true for 6ths as well if you switch the major and minor. it's just the notes will be further apart because they will be in the next octave. major seconds get back to the same note after 6 notes, it's called the whole tone scale, and it is a cliche device for a 'flashback' sort of sound. minor 2nds is just the chromatic scale, and you get back to the same note after 12. 7ths are the inverse of 2nds, again with the major/minor reversed, just like 6ths vs 3rds

023269.question: i think i now understand what is wrong with me. for my whole life i waited. i thought i could change and start making my dreams real after something specific. you know, in movies, books, motivation stories and such a big event happens or a day comes that everything changes and oh, look, now i am perfect, successful and productive. i shouldn't have waited, time is running out and it will sound like a paradox but it's not too late. i'm trying to categorize my ideas (and i think it will never end, i always create new ones and i can't stop, i feel like if i stop writing new ideas i won't be able to find the perfect one that will leave a stamp upon the world and because of this i can't begin to make these ideas real) and i find flaws all the time. it's like there is something missing in all of them and they are not perfect. like, there are silhouettes in my mind of the perfect thing but it's just black, i can't see it clearly but if i ever can do that, i will cha nge the world. so, this is the situation. what is the next step?
023269.answer: remember that no one has ever done anything perfect. all the best things that anyone has ever done, the things which you may admire the most, were actually not perfect at all. you might not know it because it's the only version of it you've seen. but the artist knows it. it's their little secret. so go ahead and start having some secrets

023306.question: I've been learning "Josie" on piano... For that part that goes "she's the raw flame, the live wire"... I'm hearing it as Am, D7, Gmaj7,Cmaj7... But the way it's voiced, I think is something like ACEG(raw), ACDF#(flame), GBDF#(live),to GBCE(wire). I think that's pretty nifty! You got those 4 chords played in succession, but with very little movement between the voicings. That got me thinking. I know there are no rules when it comes to writing harmony, and you can do whatever you think sounds good.... but do you get Bonus Points if you keep the voicings as close as possible when changing chords? I think having chords that 'bounce around' can definitely work and sound good sometimes, but there's something extra satisfying and special about having as little movement as possible.
023306.answer: this is a very standard chord sequence and harkens back to generations past that's normal, that's how it's supposed to be done those aren't bonus points, that is a passing grade that's true inverting your chords so they fit in the same range is normal, and healthy. it's like putting your meat and potatoes on the same plate

023311.question: hey bill can you give me some advice? i have aspergers, and i have been discriminated A LOT for it, which totally wrecked my self esteem. trough out middle and high school i've been treated like i'm a fucking retard. so much that even I believed i was a retard. i refused to shut up about having aspergers / being autistic tho, because i want people to know who i am. when i was 21 i decided to turn things around and stop telling anyone i was autistic, and tell the people who knew / still tought i was, i told them that the diagnosis was not right. not because it wasnt right, i dont know it if it was right. but that diagnosis made people not treat me right, and refuse to listen to who i actually am because the assumed they already knew, because they had read an article about aspergers or something. so right now in my life hardly anyone knows i used to wear this label. it feels good because for once people will actually listen to who i am instead of assum e. BUT t he misconceptions about aspergers remain. even with new people in my life, some of these people still think autistic = retarded / incapable of anything except math. i feel bad because by shutting up about my diagnosis i am not helping other who still get discriminated. should i 'come out' again as having aspergers? so that people will know people with aspgergers actually all have a different personality that is build up of many layers just like everybody else?
023311.answer: i say flip it, instead of letting someone else (mr. asperger) name your personality after them, why don't you try naming other peoples' personalities after you

023330.question: If you were in a jam where everyone(guitar, Bb trumpet, bassist, drummer, and you on keys) was in G minor, and the tempo was 115 bpm, and all the jam was was just a repeating two bar sequence of one bar of Gmin6 then one bar of Gmin, how would you solo, without a prior melody to framework how you should play? or would you typically avoid this kind of situation?
023330.answer: this should be a very open jam. a lot of room, everyone should listen to each other. g dorian should technically be your home base but you're free to go to mars. especially if you are the only chordal instrument and it's your solo, you can go anywhere really. the bass player should be listening and supporting where you're going. technically your home base is g minor / g dorian but there is plenty of room to go totally wild, because there is nothing really happening in the chords

023490.question: so i began composing. I have a super great accompaniement that i'm really happy with, but i can't find for the life of me a good lead line. any tips?
023490.answer: i think most of the time it seems to be better to do it the other way around, but not always. if you have a good groove/accompaniment that seems good on its own, i would suggest taking hints from what's going on there, and just taking the melody straight from something that's already happening. in other words, if it already sounds so good, then that means it probably is almost enough as it is, with not too much room for anything else unrelated. so perhaps try to find the most stand-out distinctive part about it, and emphasize it more. or, another option, if there happens to be an obvious space or gap anywhere, work with that space. it seems like if what you have already seems good, as you said, then you should be very gentle when 'adding' anything

023531.question: Hi Bill! I was hoping you could maybe give me some tips on this. So, I play in a band with 2 guitarists (me being one of them). And for certain little sections in certain songs, I want to figure out a way to intertwine the rhythms of the 2 guitars in a way where it sounds like just 1 guitar, but with like a delay/echo type thing. Do you think if I play the same part the other guitarists plays, but slide the whole phrase forward like a 16th note (or maybe an 8th note?) that would kind of give it that delay/echo type sound? I don't have any recording equipment at home to experiment with.. but do you think this technique would work? Any tips or advice on how to make it sound extra crisp and natural?

023551.question: hey, so i just heard this song on the radio, i thought it was a cover of toto's africa- it was a pretty shitty cover, but i thought someone was doing a cover of it. then when i looked it up later i found out that it was a jason derulo track called "fight for you" and it doesn't mention toto or africa anywhere on it. yet it has the same chords and even the same lyrics! it occasionally cut in some terrible pop verses but man it is actually a rip off and i wanted your thoughts on this
023551.answer: it is a derivative of Africa. it is authorized, and the songwriters of Africa are properly credited and paid. popular songs very often are either covers, samples, or derivatives of previous popular songs, and most of the time the original writers are credited and paid. one of the most famous examples is "surfin USA" by the beach boys, which has the entire same melody as "sweet 16" by chuck berry, who is credited and paid for "surfin USA" also. another famous example is Gansta's Paradise, which originally a Stevie Wonder song, who is credited and paid for Gangsta's Paradise as well. Another more recent example is Sam Smith's "stay with me" which was found to have nearly the same melody as "won't back down" by Tom Petty, and after an out-of-court settlement, tom petty is now credited and paid. there are hundreds more examples, and this has been common in popular music for many generations.

023573.question: How come when you have 4 eighth notes in a row, sometimes there all 4 grouped together and sometimes it's written as 2 groups of 2? Is there a difference?
023573.answer: the rule i follow is, never beam more than 4 in a row, and don't beam across the 'imaginary barline' halfway through the bar. so if it's "1 & 2 &" beam all 4. if it's "3 & 4 &" beam all 4. if it's "2 & 3 &" beam it as 2 groups of 2 and leave the middle open. when it's the full bar, beam 2 groups of 4. for 16th notes you can apply similar rules except the 'imaginary bar line' would be between each beat, so again groups of 4 maximum, but don't beam anything across the imaginary barlines

023574.question: When you were at the 8th annual shorty awards and that nico guy performed what was going through your head?
023574.answer: well, here's the thing- they did their hit song "am i wrong" which i think is a wonderful song, and i've had a strong attachment to that song ever since i first heard it on the radio. but here's the problem (there's actually 2 problems) the first problem was their live performance had no live elements at all. it was the studio recording with the lead vocal muted. there was absolutely no live feel to it, and the studio vocals were a bit better, because it had better editing. so we were basically hearing the exact original recording, except with slightly worse vocals. the other problem was, unfortunately, the song did not go over well with the audience. they did their best to energize the crowd by shouting things like "shorty awards" and "put your hands up" etc etc, but it just wasn't working. again, i absolutely love the song and i love the recording, so this is not a complaint about the artist or the song, this is just my analysis of the situation

023578.question: Sorry if I'm oversimplifying this (I know you do all types of content... scrambles, the question page, reality, jazz, improv, notebook, etc)... But it seems like you kind of "made a name for yourself" doing all the vines and short videos. Then you didn't want to get pigeon-holed as "The Guy Who Makes Short Videos" and when your fans came to expect more and more short videos, you put out HOJ and HOTEWIG. Then when everybody started demanding more and more history videos, you didn't want to get labeled as "The Guy Who Makes History Videos". Now, it seems like your focus is music videos for medium-length songs? My question is, what happens when everyone starts demanding more music videos and you become associated with this particular form of content? Will we see another big shift? Again, sorry if I'm oversimplifying your 'creative trajectory'. Like I said, I know you do all types of stuff. I'm a big fan of everything you put out, and you've been a huge inspirat ion to me as a musician myself, and as just a fellow person tryna be a person. Thank you for everything you do.
023578.answer: i think you understand the general path very well. except, there are many elements of my past work that are unilaterally right for me, and i will continue to use. so it is not necessarily a game of always doing something completely new. it is mainly just about filling out the space of all the potential things that i think would be good for me. if you look at the discussions i was having a few years ago, there were several major 'houses' of types of content that needed to be explored, none of which had been fully explored at the time. so that's why shifts were necessary -- to make sure i explored everything that needed to be explored. medium-full length songs, with videos, is extremely important and has been important for a long time, and i've always written a huge surplus of them, so there is a lot of catching up to do. but still, free-videos (videos that are not exclusively based on 1 song) both fictional and non, is still a hugely vast area to explore, and having done such a huge amount of work on extremely short projects (due to the 4-vid-per-week schedule, and later due to the success of my vine channel) there is still a huge amount of exploring to do in the longer ranges

023634.question: re: http://www.billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201709142348 and http://www.billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201709142226 don't you think that "progression" in this case could be a helpful modifier to determine the difference between sets of chords that include the same functions but in a different order, in other words, the order of 6m-4-1-5 vs 1-6m-4-5 like in the second question? if "progression" is meaningless, it seems like "heart and soul" could sound like the same song as derulo "fight for you" or "africa", but that's clearly not the case, because derulo "fight for you" sounds like "africa" but not like "heart and soul". or there some other way you distinguish between the same chords occurring in a different order?

023635.question: I keep on writing songs that I like, but the stuff I end up writing typically doesn't work for the instrumentation I have access to at the moment. Any tips on forcing yourself to write for a specific intended purpose?

023640.question: i didn't mean that one hour long play script is one of the small steps. it's not a huge step for me but it definitely was a critical step that would help me take bigger steps forward. and i have no idea how i managed to do it either. after i took your advice i thought "this is what i want to do, this is what i do best, what stops me? i can't take doing nothing anymore." and i started to note every little and crazy idea for anything, being reckless about if it's perfect for other people's standards. i travelled and wrote poems in those places. i tried to play guitar for the first time in years, it seems i need to dust off my old skills but ... i wrote lyrics, i guess? i had many, many, many fiction ideas for novels and i gained experience for non-fiction. and i did everything on a small scale. THEN i jumped in at the deep end by accepting a task, which is this play. in fact i was going to refuse but i had to accept, 'they' made m e. the m ain theme they gave to me was very common, but safe and i was given enough time to write. for like a week i didn't even start, i didn't think about it and then i remembered and i said "okay, you know what, fuck this. they want me to do what everyone else does. i'll give them and the audience the theme they want, but i'll do it my way." and i started to write nonstop, contextualizing the subject in a way no one ever dared before. i didn't care, i was just writing and soon i realized it's finished in just eight hours. because of this success i was feeling confident, i sent them the script saying "listen to me, i am your only chance to put this play on the stage in time, here is my script, i know it's crazy but i also know it's good, accept it or accept it, i won't be directing anything other than this." politely. and they LOVED it, i must admit that i was surprised. the play will be staged three months later (which is also a short time like eight hours for a play but i'll handle it) and i might do voice acting. i'm sure they will cut out the best scenes 'because it's not appropriate' but doesn't matter. the important thing is i have the original script i have written and one day i will be able to revive it the way i want. after the play is performed i'll continue with small but fast steps because i still don't feel ready to run, just like i said before it's just the beginning. so here comes the questi on, is m y situation somehow similar to how you started doing your contents? and what do you think about how my improvement is going? it's important for me to know, you were the only person i told my problems on writing and this drowning in infinity thing.
023640.answer: no, i was never able to make connections with other people, and in turn i learned never to have to rely on others to complete my work overwhelmingly spectacular

023654.question: I have a lot of music written. Some of its fully recorded, some it's partially recorded, some it's just written out in paper. But, I have a good solid base of stuff to go off of. But right now, I'm stuck in a MAJOR rut. Like, what do I do with all this music? The logical thing I think would be pairing music with videos, graphics, or some kind of visual aspect. But the thing is, I've never really felt the "calling" of being a video-maker. It's not really something I'm passionate about at all, in the same way I am about making music... and if im not passionate about it, why even do it? Even if I do decide to at least try making videos, I have no experience in it and wouldn't even know where to begin... Also, I feel like just making videos for the sake of pairing something up with my music isn't a good strategy since it would just be like forcing 2 things together instead of creating something with sound and visuals together that go hand and hand as pa rt of a whole. I have some songs that I think can stand alone, like more traditional verse/chorus stuff with vocals... but most of my stuff is like weird little instrumental pieces, like 10 seconds to a minute in length, which I don't think would make much sense on their own (when I wrote them I had certain images in mind, like this song reminds me of a mad scientists tinkering with a bunch of test-tubes and bubbling chemicals, this song sounds like you just got "game over" in a video game, this song sounds like you just had an idea and a light bulb went off over your head, this song sounds like your taking a walk and then something crazy jumps out in front of you, this one sounds like you tried to do something epic but then failed in an anticlimactic way at the very end, etc)... sorry for this long rambling text. But I just feel like I've been standing in front of the same hurdle for a very long time and have no ideas how to jump over it and it's disheartening. If you have any advi ce for m e, I'd really appreciate it. Like should I just force myself to try to learn how to make videos, and hope that over time I learn to enjoy it, get better at it, and find my own voice/style? Or should I seek alternate routes (which routes, I don't know) that don't involve me making videos?
023654.answer: well, if you really don't want to find any way to make videos but you feel like the material has to go with something visually (which i think is probably right) then you might consider finding someone else who wants to make the videos. or, another approach would be to find people that make videos and they are looking for music, and you could write music to their videos. neither of these options work for me because i am a control freak and i live under a rock. but because of that, i knew i had no choice but to learn how to make the videos myself. but if you don't want to do that you might try to explore some collaborative options

023660.question: Hello, my name is Jeff Caan. I don't know if you like posting questions where people say there names, but in this case, I don't mind. You have my permission. My name has caused me a lot of annoyance over the years. With my last name being "Caan" I've had to deal with SO many people yelling "Khaaaaaaaaaaan!" (like from Star Trek), also, I've lost count of the times where I've had to tell people that no, I am not Shao Kahn from Mortal Kombat or Shere Khan from Jungle Book. I'm also not related to James Caan or Madeline Kahn. And in the past couple of years, I don't think I need to tell you how people react whenever I say "My name is Jeff.".... I would like to use your question page as an opportunity to give a PSA to all those who read these questions. DO NOT MAKE JOKES ABOUT SOMEBODY'S NAME. THEY HAVE HEARD THE JOKE BEFORE COUNTLESS TIMES. YOU ARE NOT ORIGINAL, AND THEY DO NOT THINK IT IS FUNNY. If somebody's name is Jesse don't say "Ha! Tha t's a gi rls name!" If somebody's name is Duncan, don't call them "Duncan Donuts". If somebody's name is Richard, yes, they know that Dick is short for Richard and that dick can mean penis. If somebody's shares the same last name as a celebrity or a character from a tv show/movie/book, don't ask them if they are related to that person/character. If somebody's first and last name rhyme or if they have "two first names", you don't have to point that out for them. They know.

023692.question: pls help bill what are the time signatures in i wanna be a movie star? i've been struggling to discover it but it's so difficult and
023692.answer: the main hook/chorus is 4+5 (alternating 4, and 5.) the verse goes 4, 5, 4, 5, 3, 3, 6 (i know you may think it makes no sense to use 3's and 6's both, but that's just the way i think of it. you could break any of these up any way you want) and the second half of the first verse is the same BUT, i can't remember, there might be an extra beat at the end of the verse, so the second time around might be 7 or 6. i remember there was some discrepancy here, different ones felt like they needed to be different ways. i haven't heard it since it was released. the end of each verse might be either 6 or 7, you'll have to count yourself, i haven't heard it since it was released and i'm not listening to it now. The chorus right before the bridge is cut short, so that entire chorus would be 4, 5, 4, 5, 4, 5, 4, 3. The bridge is 6, 7, 6, 4, 7 (you could break this up in many different ways. also not totally sure about what the hang time is on the end of the bridge, i don't remember for sure) all these times are expressed in terms of quarter notes. so when i say "5" that means "5/4"

023700.question: others don't complete my work. i don't care whoever is it, i never would let someone do that, it's MINE. i just tell people what to do. but to stage something there are other people i have to work with, the people who made me write the script and who will probably cut some scenes out. it seems it's my only choice right now, to work with them or anyone else who is able to cut until i'm ready to take bigger and faster steps. i actually want to do it on my own, right now and i'm still trying to figure out how to do such a thing alone (and i'm open to any suggestion from you). i think writing anything is meant to be done alone and i do it that way because it's the best one but shooting a film or performing a play... i really have to work with a crew (and with some people outside the crew) unless we are talking about an online monologue video here. so yeah i'm not completely free at the moment but one day i will be, i have just begun. what i'm saying is, i don't rely on others to complete my work, it's more like i command them. you definitely should try this. even if 'they' are the people i told you about, i'm the one who is in the driver's seat and i wouldn't write the script if i wasn't. letting them cut stuff is compromising, because i know the script i've written is risky, and daring.
023700.answer: right, i agree with all of this. and i do hope to do that stuff some day. the only thing is if you really want to tell a bunch of people what to do, you need to be at a reasonably high standing in society. meaning you need to be able to pay everyone adequately, at least if you want professional quality work. and if you can't afford to pay them, you have to always worry about whether they want to keep working with you, and you will be walking on eggshells, perhaps afraid to give the kind of serious direction you might want to give. Working completely alone is a different thing. it means you can't use actors, you can't have camera operators, .... you are limited to entirely different mediums, like animation, etc. and that is very hard work. like i said, it depends on your level of difficulty in working with others. if you really really can't do it (like i can't) then it might be worth it to re-imagine your entire career around things you can do yourself. at least until you have more resources. nowadays you can get further than ever working alone

023794.question: hey Bill, i just read your update on the new project and how you are looking for faster ways to make videos. This is a very relevant issue for me as well, and i have some ideas that might be of use... i started out making everything in After Effects (i dont know what software you use but this should be relevant regardless) which is great and amazing but non efficient especially when you have a identity of textures and tones that is some kind of starting point and a through line through all your different projects but reusing previous stuff from other After Effects projects feels werid and is not ideal. i have recently been learning a coding language called Processing which i am using to create programs to execute visuals before i bring them into After Effects. For a a hopefully relevant example to you, i could make a program where i can type in text, have a rgb slider for base color of text, create duplicates of text on top of one another with differ ent colo rs and choose a display style like a repeating pattern of text or a silly wobble distortion or something. Then i can save the text as a picture or video and then do the polishing in After Effects. These little programs you can make for various reasons and reused without loosing freshness or constraints as you can easily add a few parameters to the code for every projects adding on to the base you have built up which you can execute and use immediately. The beginning of this process is the worst by far and takes time but it seems to me like the efficiency ratio is a constant upward line with no plateauing and from your knowledge of html from making this website, i think the starting momentum would not be too terribly slow. this might be helpful to you, thank you for changing the world all the time
023794.answer: i would like to talk more about this! have you checked out my email address on the email page of this site

023816.question: Ya know how music is all like, "Hey bud, you can write me, but you better write me bad a lot until you write me good," and then you're like, "no, i wanna write you good right now," and music say, "nah, bud, it's gotta be bad. Later it can be good, but be bad right now," and you say, " fine, whatever," and then you make music and it is always bad and then you are like, "when will it get good," and then music is all like, "it doesn't. It is always bad, and that's really good," and then you're like, "that makes no fucking sense what are you talking about," and music says, "well, I was just thinking that maybe I could, like, inspire you by saying that music is bad and you've been making bad music so I'm just trying to show that, like, if you make the music bad it is good or something," and then there's a long pause and then you're like, "I'm gonna make good music now," and music says, "fine whatever." 023827.question: sometimes you don't have to pay people for them to make professional work. it depends on the person actually but there are other people out there who just want to express themselves by doing what they do best, i believe. if you can afford to pay them, they might keep working with you unwillingly for money and that's a problem. if you can't, authority and control will always be a problem and relationships will affect the work. yes, there are other people like us but what if we're not lucky enough to find anyone? i can't even find a fucking solution to these problems. i'm not talking about collab, i hope you understand, it's more about a crew. i'm not bad with people but i want the thing i make to be mine and i just can't follow orders. i need to be alone to be able to write anything, so poems, lyrics, stories and such are not a problem but scripts ... plays i have to direct and movies/shows i plan to make in the future feels like attaching rocks to my feet an d letting my originality sink because, you know, people. now if i don't like something i can just change it or get on the stage and perform myself but what will happen when things get more and more serious? i want to be free but there has to be a way to do it without being alone. i'm ok with being alone, i want to be, but this is never going to work for performing and shooting. since my primary goal was always writing, anything and everything, i'm used to be on my own but if i can't work this play and the crew thing out, i have to sacrifice the scripts and some of my dreams. i don't understand why this is happening. the first play took long and it consumed me but everything was good, i never thought i will do it again. i don't think it's about compromising, i was expecting that. i know i am the director and everything is under my control, just like i wanted. i really don't understand why.
023827.answer: right, but their commitment will be dependent on delicate factors, such as how your personal relationship with them might be going sure, and they also 'unwillingly' need to eat to survive ah, too real i know what you mean you will have to work your way up. i am just barely even beginning to think about scratching the surface of various types of 'crew' solutions. but in my model, people need to be paid if you really want to expect them to do work and spend time, consistently, whether it's monday or friday most people would say yes. for me, weirdly, for reasons i have never understood, again and again the answer is unfortunately no. i have gotten used to this by now it's called earth and it's rough. you gotta bury things in the dirt and stomp on it until it makes food. and you gotta keep doing it. you may even have to hire animals if u can't do it fast enough. i don't know why we're here, it's pretty, but it's rough. it has actually gotten much much easier throughout the milleinia and centuries, but i'm telling you it's rough, and i think the name of this planet actually means 'challenge.' but it's important to remember that that's what you came here for, possibly because you were bored before, or maybe for a different reason, i'm not sure

023863.question: bill i need help finding a good chord to continue a section of a song. It's on acoustic guitar but it's the top 4 strings so it's almost ukelele sounding. It goes A major with the root doubled in the G and high E strings, to Amaj7 to A7 to the chord i'm trying to find. 023863.answer: yeah you want D. then prob Dmin, then A(over C# in the bass if you prefer), then B7, then E7. and loop back. i mean i think you should write according to what the song is about and what it's used for, but i have a feeling this is what you're looking for. the D for sure. after that it's your choice

023870.question: i'm a superfan, but here's something that bugs me about you. you insist that other people cant be involved in the creation of your art, but thats a false claim. you treat this very questions page as a piece of art (which is to say, you make it exactly like you like it, exercising artistic judgement in its very existence, creating something truly beautiful and worth paying attention to) and the page's existence is entirely dependent on others -- harnessing their curiosity. I think you're just being defeatist to rule out all collaboration when you have demonstrated on some level that it is within your grasp. if anyone can come up with a game plan and a system of ensuring the collaboration is designed in such a way that it results in Desired User Experience, then it's you, and i'm saying that because you figured out the much harder puzzle of becoming unconfused about how to make anything at all. you lament the slowness of your production but rule out th e most p otent soltion instead of making it work for you, with cleverness and ingenuity. manhours are what you need to get the workrate you crave, and, right now, there are more untapped manhours at your disposal out there in the world than you have left in your entire life. ruling out the option of collaboration strikes me as so unlike your philosophy of there being so many shades of gray in every issue and challenge. i genuinely believe you can do anything you set your mind to. love, a fan for life
023870.answer: thank you for the update perhaps some of the people you call defeatist have actually tried many times, and many ways, while you weren't watching it's important to remember that that was my first choice

023893.question: I have a hard time coming up with vocal parts. And singing is especially difficult for me. I've had asthma since I was a kid, and other recurring respiratory issues.. so sometimes it's tough to hold out a note for a long time, or to sing a full phrase without having to stop to take a breath, I think it might limit my vocal range too. When I do try and sing, I sound like if Donald Fagen smoked way too many cigarettes and put a clothespin on his nose. I love music, and I like to think that I am pretty decent on the instruments I play, but so many songs are driven by the vocal parts. Like, I think really the function of instruments in a song is to compliment/accompany the vocals (which should usually be front and center)... Not really singing makes it tough for me to actually come up with vocal parts, so I try to over-compensate with the instruments when I write. But when I do play with a singer, usually there's too much going on with the in strument al arrangements and it sounds too jumbled/cluttered. Any advice for me?

023912.question: Hi. So the earth completes 1 rotation in 24 hours. That's 1/86400 seconds which is about 0.00001157407 Hz. Move that up a few octaves (22) and you pretty much got a G note. Using the same math... I found that Mercury and Venus are both closest to A. Earth and Mars are closest to G. Jupiter is closest to Bb. Saturn is closest to A. Uranus is closest to C#. Neptune is closest to D. So our solar system is playing, like a Gm9#11 chord? Why such a sad, weird, dissonant chord do you think? Why does our solar system feel like that? Pluto would be closest to B... which would make the chord even weirder.... I don't even know what you'd name that chord. Maybe this is why scientists don't want to make pluto a planet???
023912.answer: it's important to remember that those frequencies are not close enough in tune to warrant calling it the chord you called it. some of them are really like half way in between notes. i think if you are interested in what it sounds like, you will need to try putting all those frequencies together (multiplied up several octaves of course) and hear what it sounds like

023917.question: I heard this really good description of "time" in the form of a riddle from my musical mentor. He asked me "let's say you are rafting on a river. There are slow parts and fast parts. So if the fast part is going faster than the slow part, then why isn't there a gap in between the fast and slow parts where there isn't any water?" and I knew how rivers worked so I told him "the size of the river changes" and he was like "yes! That's how good time works! it can speed up or slow down, but there is always the same amount of 'water', and when people aren't very good at keeping time, there are these wedges in the river where there is empty space." I love this analogy but I still don't fully understand the "water" part in terms of music. Do you have any ideas?
023917.answer: i actually don't understand the analogy

023948.question: You know that feeling when you hear a little phrase in a song that gives you goosebumps? I've always wanted to write/play something so good that i give myself the chills, and i have never been able to do it. Sometimes when playing with a band it's happened to me, like when everything just clicks and everyone in the group is really reading each other and you can feel that connection (like sometimes when improvising or 'jamming' i get that feeling like i know exactly what my bassist and drummer are about to do, and they know exactly what i'm about to do, and it's magical)... but i think that's more about that feeling of unity, than the sound itself. Like if somebody were recording it and played it back, i don't know if i'd still get goosebumps. But never when i'm just playing by myself, or working on a recording, have i been able to give myself chills, and i've always kind of viewed that as a 'litmus test' of my songwriting/playi ng abili ty. So far, it's a test i've failed. But i don't know if that's because it's impossible to do to yourself.... Have you ever given yourself goosebumps with your own playing/writing in any of your songs? Is it even possible to give yourself the chills? I'm happy with the songs i've written, but i feel like i'm still searching for that elusive little phrase.
023948.answer: oh hell yeah yes i know exactly what you mean you can hear it too i think you do i think you're exactly right it's possible yes yes just keep writing a lot, and experimenting, and remember that there's no limits to what you can put in the song

023966.question: Am I a part of the universe? Sometimes I feel as if I am but a trespasser. One who observes and tries to watch and understand, but does not contribute. The universe placates me into complacency and boredom through shallow joys and entertainments. My friends placate each other to avoid negative emotions. Best to do nothing at all than to risk doing something bad. But a deep part of my soul stirs itself and yearns for more. I'm thinking of running away from this toxic environment and learning to play an instrument or some sort of art or something-anything- to contribute to the beauty around me. But I'm scared to take the first step. Beaten into being afraid of making even the smallest misstep. Afraid of the unknown. I want to dive into the universe rather than stay as a passive observer, but I still don't understand it well enough to find a path on my own. And I don't want to follow the footsteps of another, or I will be constantly comparing myself to them and replacing my old rules and rigidity with a new set. How do I be myself or know what I like if I have no idea what either of those things mean? How to test if something is me, or if something is what I like? My whole world is soulless and unresponsive, how do I pick up a personality without just copying others?
023966.answer: yes you'll just have to guess see if you can do it, comfortably copy multiple different people, and merge the personalities. or you could try something totally new, but that's optional, as you have surely noticed

024049.question: Do you see your whole life as a song? Choose the things you do according to the beat of a rhythm or a purpose? Then bounce around that theme randomly to try to explore all possibilities and find unexpected ways to express yourself? Listening to your music has made me start to act this way, and I think I like it, although I'm still being cautious. If your art has this effect on me, I wonder what effect the other media I consume has on my mental and emotional equilibrium. I want to use this realization as an excuse to control my mental faculties and inputs, while I also try to remind myself that if I fall too deep down that hole I will miss out on some really cool/interesting shit. Sometimes you've gotta experience the universe, sometimes you've gotta think about it, but whichever you're doing right now you should do it in a way that builds it for the future AND enjoys the present.

024051.question: writing the music is the real fun part for me, just laying down the chords and instrumentation. i like it! but 40 instrumental songs later, it feels like i'm in the same place as when i began--my skills are better, but i haven't gotten to say anything, and i need to move forwards. i've made 3 songs with words, and it's important. they were good, except recording vocals drives me crazy so the production value on that is subpar. you've really gotta have words if you wanna be clear and specific in your meaning. but lyrics only come to me sometimes, one idea at a time, and in between i'm left drifting. again, putting words to music is some of the most fun i've had making anything. but i really don't know how to just get jumpstarted at will. how can i conquer this?
024051.answer: i'm not sure, but it's important to remember that lyrics and music help each other. in other words, if you are good with music, which i suspect you are because you've been doing it along time, theoretically you could probably get away with making any lyric sound good. so try random starting places, like random word generators or something, as a starting point, and then make it a challenege to see if you can make it work

024112.question: When I write down music, I always get confused about sharps, flats and natural symbols. Like if you have a note outside of the key signature and you put a flat,sharp or natural symbol on it, by the next measure are you supposed to assume that if that same note has no symbol then it's back to normal? Or if the note is altered in one clef, but not the other, do I put a sharp/flat/natural symbol on just the one clef and leave the other one unaltered? What if there's a modulation, do I put the new key signature in the middle of the score, or do I just adjust the sharps and flats accordingly? My strategy is just to write everything as if it's in the key of C. Notes that are sharp I write the sharp symbol, notes that are flat I write the flat sumbol. I never write the natural symbol, and if a note is played with a sharp or flat multiple times in the same bar, I write the symbol each time (instead of just once). This works fine for me, because usually the only per son who reads my sheet music is me. And this system makes sense to me.... but is this a bad strategy if I were to share my music with other people?Like if I were to write something out for some horn players or a piano player or whatever, would this system throw them off do you think?
024112.answer: in situations like that i think courtesy accidentals are very important if it stays there for a significant amount of time, then put a new key signature that is sometimes called an 'open key' and it is mainly used when it's just so all over the place it's not worth putting a key signature. i used an open key for a video where i transcribed and harmonized spoken language, as music. no sense putting a key because it was all over the place. but most 'reasonable' music should have a key signature yes. accidentals last at least until the end of the bar. i always thought there was disagreement about whether or not they last until the end of the line. but they definitely last at least until the end of the bar, and you should not be repeating the symbol if the note stays that way within the same bar, and therefore you need a natural to specify if it changes back. and if it changes back right at the beginning of the next bar, probably use a courtesy natural just in case. if it's in different octaves i think the rules become a little more ambiguous and courtesies are good, i'm not sure of the exact rules when it's different octaves

I'm more just curious about my system.
024114.answer: that's true but there are some situations when it gets really dense when you might need F and F# at the same time. let's say if you are scoring a horror movie or something you might even need them in the same octave because you have F, F#, G all mashed together. i honestly have no idea how you would notate that. it is rare and only in extremely dissonant 'horror' type situations

024283.question: How do I know if I will be good at writing music or enjoy it if I don't have the instruments or money to buy instruments? 024283.answer: you're just gonna have to try some things. on one end of the spectrum, just do what feels familiar, and it may be similar to things that already existed (which is not always the biggest crime, considering 95% of music is very very similar to other music that existed before in many ways). and the opposite side of the spectrum is try things that are so outlandish that they are guaranteed to be different, even if they might be totally insane and not good. chances are you will stumble upon something good anyway. but either way it is important to try many many different things, on both sides of the spectrum, and you will very quickly learn how to fly the plane

024292.question: What do you mean by "hymnifying the second half" or "fractal-like duck form"?
024292.answer: 'hymnifying the second half' is what i sometimes call the thing in a traditional song form where the 4th 8th is the 5 chord, and the 8th 8th is the 1 chord, and the 7th 8th usually contains 1 over 5 and 5. you've heard it thousands of times. she'll be coming around the mountain, etc. Fractal like duck form is a phenomenon that occurs where the landing point of the first half is in the same relative time position as the landing point of the whole thing, relative to the whole thing. so for example, over the course of a 4 bar phrase of lyrics, let's say your first line lands halfway through the second bar, that's squarely on the 4th quarter of the first half. then your next line should have its landing point at the top of the 4th bar, which is the halfway point of the second half, and hence the start of the 4th quarter of the whole thing. so your landing point of the entire thing is in the same position relative to the whole as the landing poing of the first half was to the first half. this creates a fractal-like self-similarity that the mind responds very well to, and is present in many many lyrics/songs and rhythmic poems. here is a simple example from lil wayne, over the course of 2 bars, where the landing point of the first half is on the 4th quarter of the first half, and then the landing point of the second half is halfway thru the second half, making it on the 4th quarter of the entire thing.

024370.question: I know this is probably a tough question, but do you have any tips on writing melodies? If you give me a melody, I can arrange it (figure out harmonies, bass line, drum beats etc)... but I always hear people say that melodies just 'come to them', like they just appear out of nowhere in their heads like magic... but this has never been the case for me. I usually write a chord pattern that I think sounds interesting, then I try to build a melody from the notes in the chords. Sometimes I can do it, sometimes I can't. But I know I'm doing it backwards. Melody should come first. Melody is the most important part of a song.
024370.answer: when writing a melody, it's sometimes hard to know 'why' you're writing the melody if there's no lyric with it. like, who cares if the notes go here or there? what's it for? what is this even about? but when you are delivering a message, through words (musical words) then all of a sudden everything has meaning. i'm not suggesting you do lyrics first, that route seems bland as hell to me. i'm suggesting you do lyric and melody at the same time. perhaps other people do it differently but that's the only way it goes for me

024408.question: Hi Bill! Sorry if you're tired of getting hotewig questions.. but I'd like to know more about your thought process/goals for writing the intro part. After the big bang, there's pretty much a straightforward story line for you to follow (if you can call the history of the world straightforward)... but everything from "hi, you're on a rock..." up until "i think there's a universe now" must've been really tricky to write. The origin of the universe (and history of the universe) seems like a real tough story to set the scene for. Did you find it hard to come up with a good intro for the video? (Btw I think you nailed it).
024408.answer: that was probably the most fun part. explaining the motivations for a universe happening, from the perspective of there not being a universe. and it's really common sense, i think, if you look at it from the right perspective, but the problem is you are not allowed to properly use time or space in the description because those things only exist if there is a universe. and most language as we know it is based on time and space. so it makes for some thrilling turns of phrase

024498.question: you always say that lyrics can give meaning to a melody and even guide it's magic ways. but don't you think that a melody can tell a story alone with no lyrics? seems a bit like you underestimate instrumental music? I agree with you that it is much harder do appeal do people if you have no lyrics, but still..
024498.answer: yes no, trust me, i am Hard-Wired as an instrumental musician. in my childhood i listened to only instrumental music, and didn't know how to really deal with anything else. the first many years of my musical development were vastly instrumental only. mostly artists who's music was marketed as instrumental music, in its own right. but there is an elephant in the room, which everyone always thinks about, which is "why do those instrumental artists never seem to be as successful as non-instrumental artists, even though *we* (musicians) 'know' they're 'better' " etc etc sad face. i just didn't feel like going along with such a sad conclusion so i was driven to understand, so i erased everything i knew and started listening to pop radio all day. anyway, that's beside the point, what i'm trying to say is, over time it became crystal clear that instrumental music operates in the back part of your brain, but the labels, the handles, the latches, the characters, the *cognition* as the scientists would call it, happens in the 'front' part of your brain. i guess it's called the frontal lobe, or the neo-cortex, or whatever .. (not a brain expert really) but it's kind of like where you file things. it's what you name things. even if the *feelings* and the deep stuff are all happening on a much deeper level, you will always have them 'filed' or 'named' in a particular way. and each person may file things differently. but that's what i realized about instrumental music. vastly powerful, usually doing most of the real heavy lifting in terms of actually making the over-all product feel good, does all work in terms of pulling the heartstrings, BUT the frontal 'handles' (characters, words, names, titles, etc etc, the frontal stuff) will always seem to get the credit. that's just the way it works. and the same is true for my childhood listening to instrumental music -- for example, let's say an album of instrumental music is sold under a particular musician's name, and they play a certain instrument (let's say it's piano). that's the 'frontal' content, the label / title etc... in other words, when you listen to it, you are 'cognizant' of the fact that you are listening to a piano player's music. you are aware that that is what's happening. so if that reality is something you are comfortable with, then you will be comfortable listening to that music. where-as, take for example, a movie, with scenes in it about troubles in a relationship due to long distance separation, etc etc etc, but it happens to be underscored by piano. you are still listening to instrumental piano music, but you whole idea of what's happening will be different. you will probably think of it as 'i'm watching this scene in a movie about these characters etc this is what's going on" rather than "i'm listening to piano music" ... now not everyone necessarily files things the same way, because for example someone interested in film scoring could easily be listening to it and hearing the underscoring, and that's likely a main reason they would be watching the movie, to specifically enjoy the underscoring. but even so, that reality is still different from listening to a piano player's album, because the film-scoring person is not just listening to the score, but they are listening to it from a film-scorers perspective. when we are studying and learning things, that often determines the angle we focus on. another example, let's say it comes from a video game. the music will have all it's power but it will be connected with the game, and the game will again act as the 'handle' or 'filing system' that sort of 'delivers' the music to the listener, and in turn the music is richly juicing up the contents of the game, to feel so much more meaning, and again usually the 'handles' (the content of the game) will get all the credit. unless, again, it is a music student or a musician listening, in which case That would be their 'handle.' so even when instrumental music seems to be purely insrumental with nothing else, there is always some context in which the listener heard it. for example, let's say you are walking down the street and all of a sudden you randomly hear instrumental music coming out of a fire-hydrant. well guess what, that's not just detached music, that's music you heard coming out of that fire hydrant, and when you tell the story you will always remember that music as the music that was coming out of that fire hydrant. so in that sense the only way to actually have completely unfiled unassociated instrumental music is if you were hearing the music and you literally don't know where it's coming from and you also don't know where you are, and also don't remember the circumstances that led to you not knowing where you are. so basically my point is that yes truly and surely instrumental music has all the powers. but it is made of liquid and you really can't drink any of it unless you have a cup

024520.question: Hi Bill. So I'm thinking about looking for work as a piano teacher, just to make some extra $$$. I've never really put much thought into how I'd teach music, starting from square one, to a beginner. What do you think would be a really good thing to do for a first lesson for someone who has never played before? I don't mean to sound conceited or anything like that, but I started playing so young that I really don't remember first learning. Other people in my family play, so I was probably just banging on the piano as a baby. By the time I first started taking lessons as a kid, I already had a very basic 'feel' for the piano (like I was able to pick out really simple melodies by ear, knew some chords, and was able to play extra simple stuff with both hands at the same time). What do you think would be a good first step for someone starting from nothing? Do you remember first learning to play piano?
024520.answer: discovering (on their own) the intense joy and power that comes from pressing the notes, and hearing how the sounds compare to each other me neither me too me too you and i are biased, because we learned completely on our own from an extremely young age. unfortunately, 90% of your students will be nothing like this. i think you are gonna hate teaching and i think you are gonna cancel all your lessons after the second week. that's just my best guess at what is going to happen here i have very faint memories of things like playing all the Cs really quickly up and down the keyboard, and i have very vague memories of understanding the C+E harmony, and its sister harmony, D+F. but i must have been only about 3 years old then and i don't remember ever not knowing those things

024717.question: it's a known fact, and proven countless time that isolation and lack of human contact is the worst pain a human can suffer, but in your case it seems that not creating is the worst pain you can suffer, and that you'd rather be alone and create than the opposite, how come ?
024717.answer: yeah i know it's pretty bad that's true too well i'm not necessarily alone by choice. i've probably talked about this before, but that's an ongoing question. throughout school i was always very aware that i wanted so badly to be 'included' and have a great group of friends and have lots of fun, but that consistently never became a reality, year after year, for reasons i could never figure out. but there was another thing happening too, which was that i sort of had an infinite world of musical and artistic vision going on, which no one else seemed to relate to. it seems there were infinite things i wanted to figure out and create. and i was always extremely disappointed that no one seemed capable or willing to go on this journey with me. and i think every time i tried to fit in, the reality is that i probably couldn't hide the fact that i was bored with everyone. i was trying not to be, because i wanted so bad to fit in and have friends, but i think in most cases people thought that it was ME who was not interested in THEM. anyway, this pattern continued on and on, through school and beyond. and i continued to develop my skills and ideas fiercely and passionately, sort of regretting being alone but making the most of it, and also clinging on to various threads of social contact .... until one day in a particularly bad season socially (like really there was no one to hang out with), i hit a turning point and realized that i've always known i could and should accomplish something really really serious with my life, and i should probably just accept the fact that i'm going to do this alone. and that's when i really really got serious and professional about it, and keeping journals, and really just working toward it even more seriously than before. that was years ago, and since then i have really no longer had that 'panicked' feeling of being alone -- i accepted it as part of the picture, and never looked back. and i've gotten an insane amount of work done and launched my career. and it's been so many years now that i am totally comfortable and used to the alone-ness, but occasionally maybe a couple times a year it just gets really really annoying

024738.question: Hi Bill. I don't really understand what you mean when you say things like "i sort of had an infinite world of musical and artistic vision going on, which no one else seemed to relate to. it seems there were infinite things i wanted to figure out and create. and i was always extremely disappointed that no one seemed capable or willing to go on this journey with me"... Maybe that was the case when you were younger, or maybe even with people you've met or talked to face to face... But, you have so many huge fans (like millions of people probably) of the stuff you make, and judging by this question page, so many artists/musicians/writers who view you as a major influence and inspiration (myself included). So, I am confused why you think that people don't relate to what you're doing, or that people wouldn't love to go on your journey with you.

024754.question: 10.6.17 6:18 pm Not to be argumentative or anything... you obviously know your situation better than I do... but maybe people want to work with you because they really dig what you're doing, and not because they just want to get publicity out of it? Although, I'm sure you get things on both sides of the spectrum with this. The whole "collab" thing has become very fake, like 2 people pretending to be friends, who really don't know each other at all, doing a video together only because their managers or promoters or whoever arranged it for them. Then they'll beat the dead horse of doing some kind of 'challenge vid' or some other over-done concept just for the sake of advertising eachother's channels to the other person's fan base... I'm not saying I think you should feel pressured or obligated to collaborate with other people or anything like that, but maybe it's kind of an over-generalizatio n to say that other people are only interested in working with you for publicity's sake? Like, man, if I lived in NY I'd be emailing you all the time to try to convince you to get together and jam with me hahaha... I wouldn't want it to be recorded or put up on the internet. I'd just love to play music with you.

I have a lot of music and artwork that I want to put online (maybe make my own website, but I gotta figure out how to do that)... but I'm kind of torn because, and again maybe I'm being childish, but I'm afraid to share it because I'm afraid of being ridiculed. There's a lot of heavy, deeply personal stuff that comes out in my lyrics and my drawings that I have never expressed or shared with the people I know. And if any of them see it, it would be dropping a huge bombshell on them, changing their perceptions of me. I'm not really afraid of people not liking it, moreso just people thinking 'what the fuck, man'... I have no problems sharing the stuff I make with complete strangers.. but the thought of having friends or family see it is just downright terrifying for me (nobody even knows that I draw or write lyrics/sing... 025286.question: What do you think about the whole 'tension and release' thing for writing harmonies? (Maybe it's used in reference to melody/rhythm too, but I usually hear it in reference to harmony). I know you say that the 'best' chord is the one that best supports the melody, but any melody can be harmonized in like a billion different ways, each giving its own unique character to the melody. When you're writing a song do you consciously think about dissonance & consonance or tension & release? For me, I kind of base it off the lyrics and/or how the melody makes me feel. Do you think the whole tension/release thing is more just like a metaphor to describe the function of harmony in a song? Or is it like a tool, or a lense you can look through when writing?
025286.answer: i think those terms are possibly too nebulous be anywhere near as helpful as listening to the actual sound of the harmonies you are using, or considering using i listen to the way the music sounds if you are looking for something that you couldn't already hear from listening the music, i don't think you're going to find it the only lense i look through is the way the music sounds, including all the words and their sounds and the way the whole thing sounds together with the music. there might be other lenses but i don't use them

Bill says chosen without reason blah blah preferably by computer to eliminate accidental reasoning I feel the particular response to be inadequate due to some research "One thing that traditional computer systems aren't good at is coin flipping," says Steve Ward, Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. "They're deterministic, which means that if you ask the same question you'll get the same answer every time. In fact, such machines are specifically and carefully programmed to eliminate randomness in results. They do this by following rules and relying on algorithms when they compute." You can program a machine to generate what can be called "random" numbers, but the machine is always at the mercy of its programming. "On a completely det erminist ic machine you can't generate anything you could really call a random sequence of numbers," says Ward, "because the machine is following the same algorithm to generate them. Typically, that means it starts with a common 'seed' number and then follows a pattern." The results may be sufficiently complex to make the pattern difficult to identify, but because it is ruled by a carefully defined and consistently repeated algorithm, the numbers it produces are not truly random. "They are what we call 'pseudo-random' numbers," Ward says. - MIT School of Engineering How do you feel about this? Will you stay with your stance of preferring computers to eliminate accidental reasoning or have you been influenced to believe that the machine can never trump human creativity
025338.answer: if you just take a number value associated with the current time, on a very small scale, and convert it to mod7 for example, (if you are looking for a number from 1 to 7) you will easily get random choices that no human user could ever manipulate. but furthermore, there are even some more advanced techniques happening on random.org which enables it to easily give me random sequences of numbers which are more than good enough for anything i could possibly need random numbers for

025362.question: 10.16.17 12:57 pm I think you said that you mostly use a voice memo thing for getting ideas down when they come to you... do you usually just sing the main melody? Are you able to come up with chords/harmony in your head, and if so, how would you record that? What about drum parts/bass line?
025362.answer: melody, lyric, then just explain anything else that seems important or not obvious. chords for a melody are often obvious. like when you draw a duck's head, it's pretty much assumed that you're gonna have a duck's body there too. another important thing is to count it off, because a melody sung out of thin air can be ambiguous about where the top of the bar is. so i might count off, might orient the key in case it's not clear, might clarify what the chords are if necessary, and for the groove i might quickly sing something or might compare it to another song's groove, for reference. if i have a keyboard available i might play/sing a quick demo. i often over explain, especially in terms of count-off, because new ideas can disappear easily and you might not know how the time is oriented so i try to be as clear as possible

025370.question: What's the point in using double flats and double sharps when you can just write the note a whole step higher? This has perplexed me for quite a while.

025404.question: I never understood the circle of fifths Also why is it fifths and fiths?
025404.answer: i think if you look at keys, like the key of C, ..... then look at the key of G. you'll notice that the key of G uses exactly the same notes as the key of C but you only have to change one note. then if you look at the key of D (which is in the same relation from G as G was from C) you'll notice again that D contains almost exactly the same notes as G, but you just have to change one note. and so on. the next key in the same pattern would be A. again, you only have to change one note from the key of D to get the key of A. each time you're adding a sharp, and it's always in the same position relative to the new key (it's always the 7th degree). perhaps the circle of fifths seems a little more useful now. it goes the other way too, except instead of adding a sharp you are taking away a sharp, or if there's none left then a flat gets added

025473.question: do you ever have ideas that seem fine by themselves but not when you put them together and if so how do you deal with that
025473.answer: well in general i find that it's not a happy strategy to just be frankensteining ideas together. in fact that has never once worked for me. instead what really only seems to work is to custom make the second idea knowing that it's going to go with the first idea. so that means if you have an idea in your idea collection that feels like the second part of something, you're going to have to work backwards and come up with the first part knowing it's going to go to lead into the second part. i should add a disclaimer because sometimes i get hate mail on this subject -- just to clarify, there is surely nothing wrong with combining 2 separate ideas into 1, and it may work very well for other people but it has never worked for me

025480.question: Why can't Americans write dates in the correct order or at least like a logical order or something?
025480.answer: it's based on the way it is spoken. the year is last because it is usually the least important in conversation, and the reason it is month-day and not day-month is because it is fewer syllables to say month-day. this combination of circumstances is what resulted in the date format. you might think this creates an imperfect logistical outcome, but it is important to remember that when dealing with computers and numerical sorting, it is done in the logistically correct way

025523.question: How would I voice "a" minor if i was playing in a c major scale. It seems like if I were to voice it in accordance to comfort I'd spell it like a "C6" chord.(like: C,E,G,A) so it doesn't seem right, is there a better voicing?
025523.answer: that's totally fine, (and you probably don't even need the A note) as long as there is an A note in the bass register. that is going to determine whether your chord sounds like a type of C chord or an A chord. the bass player has this power over every chord, deciding whether each chord sounds like a major chord or its relative minor. so be nice to your bass player and if possible never allow your music to be played through built-in smartphone or tablet speakers
