025592.question: I feel like I'm stuck on a plateau in terms of creativity/skill and don't know how to keep climbing up. I know the solution is not think about how 'good' my stuff is and just to keep writing, which I am doing.. but I'm getting frustrated and having a hard time being satisfied with the stuff I make. When I was first learning I could write something super simple using just open chords or something, and I'd fall in love with it. Be so proud of it and show off my new song to all my friends.. The funny thing is I like a lot of those first songs I wrote just as much, if not more, than the stuff I'm doing now. And I think a lot of it has to do with the mindset I had then. I remember first learning how to play a C7 chord and thinking 'Oh man, this is so cool!!' Have you ever felt like you reached the top of a plateau? How did you turn your plateau back into a mountain?
025592.answer: no i think you are up against a simple nostalgia problem. nostalgia gets us again and again, and it goes in waves. soon you will realize that anything you've ever done is no more 'special' than any new thing you can now do. and the things you did then were once things you had never done, where perhaps back then you were emotionally attached to some other previous thing. you will eventually get out of this by just putting on your hustling cap and doing whatever you can, do many many many things, just jump in and start going crazy. the bad news is you will probably have nostalgic feelings later for this, looking back. and then you just repeat the cycle

025609.question: So my parents aren't musicians but my mom tells me she used to obsessively play classical music a bunch while she was pregnant with me. I didn't touch a keyboard until I was 6 or 7. Anyway, now I'm 20 and I've been doing music stuff for like 10+ years with few lessons(or direction) but I know middle "C" indefinitely. And because I know "C" i can figure out every other note too(maybe I'm not explaining this right) my point is i can figure out any notes to a thing as long as I think from "C" first. I explained this to my teacher and he was like "that's perfect pitch" but I always thought perfect pitch was effortless. Honestly it doesn't matter much to me cuz I got to where I was thinking I'm relative pitch so even if I don't have perfect pitch It's not like it's impossible to be good with relative. I was just wondering I you ever heard of this kind of thing. Take care. -bro-bro
025609.answer: right. you have a very effective and wily workaround, which i have as well right. to be a musician, relative pitch is 100% required. perfect pitch (otherwise known as "absolute pitch") really doesn't have anything to do with music and is not required at all to be a good musician, and is really not even a reliable indicator of good musicianship but here's the ironic thing: there are many many people who frolic all over the place telling people they have perfect pitch, but whenever you test them, they're not even close. my point is, if you have the skill that you have (springboarding off a strong memory of C) then not only can you get the job done, but you can probably do it better than most people who actually claim to have it. so i say you might as well just say you have it. to increase your strength, familiarize yourself with where a low C is in your vocal register, (you can usually hum it quietly, should be a casual and easy note for a male, if you are a male) and just practice trying to find that note while other songs are playing. also familiarize yourself with the key of every song you've ever heard, and always learn what key songs are in. this will help you even more. perfect pitch (absolute pitch), or the sneaky workaround you have, is not at all required to be a wonderful and great musician, BUT it will provide you with an extra edge in professional situations

025659.question: 10.23.17 7:22 pm Don't ever feel bad about not having perfect pitch. Perfect pitch sounds all well and good and has a nice name, but it's just a tool. 025861.question: What's it called when you divide the beats into 6 equally spaced hits, like if the time signature is still 4/4 but instead of playing 16th notes you play 6 (instead of 4) for each beat? I'm guessing they're not called 24th notes lol. How would you write that out?
025861.answer: well, computer programs actually sometimes do call it 24th notes, just because it's consistent, mathematically. But, ... in writing it is usually called some type of triplet or sextuplet. in your situation, i would prefer to call it "16th note triplets" for clarity's sake, although i'm sure people would just say 'sextuplets' and assume you know what they mean. i prefer to write it as a group of 6 notes, double beam, except only a single beam between the 3rd and 4th notes. so 2 groups of 3 16th notes, connected in the middle by a single beam. you can put the triplet arc (and number 3) over each group of 3. or if you want i guess you could put one arc over the whole thing and put 6. that works too, i guess. i hope that answers your question

025902.question: So is your last note written in 2016 and you are updating the notebook page with previously written notes?
025902.answer: well, it really depends what counts. which has been an ongoing blurred line for quite some time. particularly after i started writing for twitter regularly in 2014. nowadays each update for "new" content to the notebook page actually consists of mostly combing through all my tweets and picking out which ones seem to be more central to me, and weeding out the ones that seem to just be composed to fill space on twitter. then uploading them and tracking down the dates, preferably when it was written, not when it was tweeted (there is often a several day difference.) and ALSO a new notes update entails going through my files and finding other things that i have written which might work well exclusively for the notes page. but there are less and less of those, over time, because while i used to use text as both an outlet for journaling and creativity, nowadays my primary outlet for journaling is audio recordings, and my primary outlet for creativity is audio/visual content. so what's happening is, in terms of newly written content for the notebook page, the vast majority of it will be things that have already been released on twitter. so in other words, when i do the next big "new" notebook update, it's going to be 95% tweets that you would have already seen if you follow my twitter page. and if you follow my twitter page you will see a new tweet every day. in addition i am constantly filling in more and more content from the past (much longer stuff, not tweets). people constantly ask my "why i don't use the notebook page anymore" but i continue to use it for the same purpose i have always used it, and furthermore if you want to see the new content, it's on twitter, every day. i hope that makes sense

026103.question: Any tips on what I should look for in getting a vocal mic (like one I can plug into my computer to record singing, not for live performance). I know you don't want to advertise a specific brand or model or anything.. but are there like, I don't know, particular features or something like I should look for? Or are they all the same and it's just the more expensive ones sound better? I really have no experience or knowledge about recording singing, so I'm not sure what to look for or where to start.
026103.answer: if you want to know my strategy, it is: use whatever you already have. if you literally don't have anything that is in any way capable of recording your voice (and i think you do, but in case you live in the desert or something) then use the one that is absolutely easiest for you to obtain. don't do a damn thing better until you are used to the way it sounds and know what you can do with it. if you 'don't know where to start' then it's not time for you to give a damn about which mic you use. it's time to give a damn about whether someone can understand the words you are saying. 120 years ago they made records out of wax, and they had a damn good time doing it

026985.question: the night before last i had a dream that my cats were being mysteriously cloned and i couldn't tell my original cats from the clones and it was stressing me out because i didn't know which ones were the ones i knew and loved. they didn't all look exactly the same, it was like how identical twins look mostly the same but have some differences (and identical twins basically are clones, they're two split from one). one of them was much easier to tell each different one apart because she has a particular pattern but the other one is just solid black floof and it was impossible to tell those ones apart. but even with the patterned one i couldn't find the one that could actually be her because none of them had the correct misshapen white star on her back, and i keep comparing all the different cats with all the different incorrect white patches, and i sort of decided one had to be her and sent the rest off, one to my grandfather next door, but as i did th at i beg an to have second thoughts and realized the one i sent to my grandfather was most likely her and i ask my brother if he could see about getting her back from him but he tells me that he didn't want to deal with having a cat so he went and got it euthanized the same fucking day. and then i kicked myself for not just checking which cats had an rfid chip and now my fucking cat is fucking dead, and then i feel guilty about all the other cats because it's not like they don't matter because they weren't any less real but i could only deal with the two who had known me and all those other ones didn't give a shit about me because they didn't know me. they were pretty much feral. and i kept trying to keep them all from hurting themselves in the house like a tiny albino floofy one getting stuck in a small water glass and having to pull it out before it drowned, and when i would they would just walk off without any acknowledgement and they didn't come close to warming up to me in any w ay. and then i thought about if one of the clones had gotten euthanized instead. would i have even Cared? if i had found my cat one of the other cats would have been deprived of its newfound life, and by her being sent to my grandfather rather than the clone that otherwise would have been, they were granted the opportunity to live and do their own kitty thing. but it still hurt. it felt like i'd failed her, because i had. but i would have failed the other cat that would have taken her place. i didn't have a dream last night because i didn't sleep last night. not because of all this but because my sleep schedule is #craycray and instead of sleeping at night i look at your website. just thought i would share because i have no one else to share it with and it was bothering me but i didn't want to forget about it. i figured writing it out would help me remember it better and i've got the questions page pulled up so why the hell not
026985.answer: this could never happen because a clone would be a new born kitten, and would take quite a while to grow into a cat that looks like your other cat

027019.question: opinion on bohemian rhapsody?
027019.answer: actually i have an interesting story about that song. i had never heard it until one time i was at a large music festival (i don't remember how i ended up there) and a band (i think a famous band, perhaps the flaming lips, maybe someone else, i'm not sure) was playing that song and they had an animated lyric video playing behind them. it was the first time i had ever heard that song, and i had no idea if it was an original or a cover or what, but the point i'm trying to make is they had an animated lyric video playing, and all the lyrics were precisely timed with the music and it was very thrilling, especially considering the already thrilling nature of that song. i think seeing that video with that song might have had a deep influence on me, and really showed me the power of using lyrics dramatically on screen with good timing

027181.question: Every time I try to actively write music, I get hung up on the fact that there is really a limited number of ways to write a song. I'm a jazz guitarist and I know my chords super well. Every key, every extension, every inversion (thats physically possible to play). I try to rhythmically spruce up my progressions, but I really feel that the core of harmony (tonic, dominant, and predominant functional chords) is limiting. I, iii, and vi share two notes, ii and IV share two notes, and V and vii are basically interchangable. I got into modal interchange when I started to feel bored with diatonic progressions. At this point, I feel like I've emptied my bag of tricks. This is basically the ultimate struggle of composition. People have been trying to answer this question for hundreds of years. How do you combat the limitations of writing music? In other words, how do you push out so much material and still hold a constant level of creativity wit h what y ou write?
027181.answer: ah, that's not true it seems you've left out one of the most important elements of a song, and one of the strongest sources of identity and guidance, in a song. and that's WORDS

more or less as a person based on my abilities but a person needs to feel competent at something and they need an outlet otherwise their brains will rot and liquify and pour out of their ears and i think mine did a long time ago. i think this page is the best thing that happened to me in years or maybe even ever because at least i have one place where i can go crazy without fear of judgmen t and it's not just shouting into a void, there's a real guy on the other end who sees it and might actually give a shit about it on some level, and it gives him an opportunity to have some fun in one tiny 027865.question: Why do you think 'pop hate' is such a common thing? Specifically with music too, there doesn't seem to be nearly as much hate directed towards 'popular' movies or books or art, etc. I always hear/read those 'music was so much better back in the day' things too, when a lot of those bands that people loved from 'back in the day' were pop bands (i.e. the beatles). Sorry, long rambling question.. but I don't know, just curious what your thoughts are on all this stuff.
027865.answer: there are many reasons why everyone will always be upset that everything "sucks" "nowadays" and it was "better" at a "previous time that i'm thinking of", but i can tell you 2 very important reasons it may be tempting to feel this way. one very simple reason is that when you listen to music from the past, it has already gone through many years of quality control filtering, and mostly the only surviving items would naturally be the 'better' ones. but if you listen to music in the present, you will hear everything that anyone is trying to do, including the stuff that won't even 'make it' to next week. for example, if you took a time machine to let's say 1975, or 1955 who cares when (you pick a time, it doesn't matter), and you turn on the radio, sure you would hear the classics that you've heard of, but along side that you would hear 3 other songs who are desperately trying to copy that one. listen to some "air check" recordings, from any year, it doesn't matter which year, listen to them and i think that should put things in perspective. Also, the other very simple reason why everyone always says that things are never is good as they used to be is just simple nostalgia. everything always seems perfect in the past. we forgive anything for sucking. and finally a 3rd reason even though i only said i was going to give 2, a 3rd reason is if you actually are a musician/artist or someone who deeply wishes to succeed, it can just boil down to jealousy and envy. and i just thought of a 4th reason, people engage in pop-hate as a way to fit in. if you bad-mouth something new, you are less likely to receive resistence because it less likely that that piece has accumulated a sizeable body of respect in society

028331.question: What the heck are modes for? Like, I get that it's basically taking a scale and changing the starting point (D dorian is C major, but starting on D, and E phrygian is C major but starting on E, etc).. but, like, what does any of that have to do with playing or writing music? I never really understood the significance of modes. I never think about them when playing or writing music.

028368.question: 12.31.17 4:29 pm Oh, ok. Playing the different modes while keeping the root the same is actually a big help in hearing the different qualities of each one. Thanks! But, wouldn't thinking in terms of modes mostly come in handy when you have a song where the harmony is just kind of vamping on 1 chord for a long time (or maybe multiple chords, but that change slowly.. as in, one chord every few bars or whatever)? I guess it's really important to establish what the root is. Like C lydian is technically G major, so if you want it sound lydian and not like G major, you really gotta focus in on C and F# in the melody and hammer it in that you're not in plain old G major. I guess thinking in terms of modes is mostly useful when you're really going for that specific quality/sound the modes have? The way I was taught it (way back when I was taking lessons still) was to use modes when 'soloing over chord changes'. Like, if you have (to chose a boring, textbook example) a I-vi-ii-V in C, that you think ionian over the I, aeloian over the vi, dorain over the ii and mixolydian over the V. But that was never helpful to me to think in those terms.
028368.answer: yes, i would say so. a famous example is "so what" by miles davis. (dorian). another example would be "the way you make me feel" by michael jackson which i just realized is a bar by bar chord rip of "on broadway" (mixolydian) or at least before they go to the 4 chord it just vamps on mixolydian. dorian and mixolydian are really the main ones that you are going to find useful in "music." lydian, like i said, comes in handy if you want to create the childlike wonder found in the opening of a 1990s steven spielberg movie, and "ionian" and "aeolian" are just another name for regular major and regular minor. the other remaining 'strange' ones are not so useful because if u are gonna be strange you are better off being strange on your own without restriction just play and see what works i think the point of modes is so we have an easy name for that time when you want a minor scale but u want to keep the natural 6. (dorian). or that time when u want a major scale but you want the flat 7 (mixo). that's the main way modes are used, in the business. and no one ever says 'modes' really, you would just say "major", "minor", "dorian", or "mixo." as far as the sequence of 7 'modes', that's just a red herring, to throw young music students off the trail and confuse them and get them to think they don't understand music when in reality music is as easy to understand as tender lovemaking ew, that's terrible advice, when playing over 1,6,2,5 sequence in C, just play in C! more specifically just get used to playing over 1,6,2,5 in C. and like maybe learn how to hit the F note when it lands on the d minor, but your ears (if you have them) should easily point you there. if you are thinking about an entire 'scale' for each chord individually you are going to have a very bad time and the listener will too

028626.question: Why do song ideas always come to me at the most inconvenient times? When I'm at work, or at the grocery store, or just out in public in general? Whenever I can, I try to write the music down or sing it into my phone ASAP. But when I'm at work, I can't just bust out a pad of staff paper and start writing or start singing into my phone. Or, if I'm on the train or something I don't want to just be singing into my phone when there's all these other people around me. I really feel like (unless it's something really short and really simple) the idea gets lost (or at least altered) if too much time passes between having the idea and trying to record the idea. What do you do when an idea pops into your head and you just for whatever reason can't record/write it out on the spot? Have you stopped caring about people's reactions and will just whip out a phone or voice recorder and sing stuff on the train or at the store or something?
028626.answer: ideas are very playful. that is their way of being playful yes you can yes you can. you can do it quietly, and professionally that is 100% true, that's because it's the first time you've heard it. that's why it's so vitally important to document it immediately i have my ways there are ways of doing it quietly and professionally, and if i absolutely can't speak, i can document the idea using text alone, and indicate the notes, rhythm, and chords using an elaborate number system. it's tedious and it takes quite a moment, and autocorrect might kick my ass, but it can be done

028628.question: Sometimes when playing music I'll use string sounds and wind/brass sounds but I play all the parts myself on piano. (I have a pretty decent keyboard and these parts actually sound not too fake). I'd love to one day actually get to play with some horn players or string players. But it's weird writing for instruments you don't play, because I don't know if these parts are playable. I try to stay in their range but there's a whole lot i don't know about the mechanics of these instruments. Like i don't know how long of a phrase a horn/wind player can realistically play without needing space for breathing in between notes/phrases. How fast certain instruments can play or how long they can hold out notes, can this instrument slide up/down to notes and play in between pitches or is it set pitches, stuff like that. I'm worried that I'll spend all this time writing and finally meet musicians to play these parts and they'll be like "dude, that's not possible t o play o n this instrument". I've been on the flip side of this where a piano player has tried to write guitar parts for me, but some of the chord voicings weren't physically possible to play on a guitar. Do you have any experience in this kind of thing, or any advice you can offer?
028628.answer: each time you will learn a little bit more

028643.question: Does C13 assume that the 9th and 11th are part of the Chord(as well as the 1,3,5,7 whatever)? If so if you were to to have a C13 with a #11 would that be C13(#11) or D/Cmaj7?
028643.answer: i'm gonna venture out on a limb and say if you see C13 written, you should probably play Bb, E, and A, and maybe D. (bass would take C). if they wanted F#, they should have told you so. if they want F, they should say sus4 and you should NOT play E in that case. that's just my experience from out in the world or whatever by the way, C13 uses Bb, not B. when maj/min is not specified it means dominant which means flat 7. C7 has a flat 7, not natural 7. for natural 7 you would need to say Cmaj7. again that's just my experience from being in the biz

028732.question: Why is the harmonic minor scale called 'harmonic' and the melodic minor is called 'melodic'?
028732.answer: if i had to guess, i would say it's because the harmonic minor scale (that means you use natural 7 but flat 6) seems to be what you get as a result of using (let's say it's the key of C minor) the G7 chord. you need that B natural note to make the G7 tick, and you might as well keep the Ab around (i.e. G7b9 or whatever). but sometimes melodies want to go 5,6,7,8 (so la ti do) kind of like that disney movie with the brooms dancing or whatever. so that would be the melodic minor scale. that one is usually only used on the way up

028855.question: if something is your favorite, that means that it is the thing you prefer. it does not mean that that thing is better than the other things, it's just the one that you prefer. for example, my favorite fruit is the apple. if I walk into a fruit store and the shopkeeper asks me what I would like, I would say "give me an apple, please". perhaps the next person in line might prefer a grapefruit, or a plum, or a banana.. and that is just fine. but I would prefer an apple over a grapefruit, plum, or banana. that doesn't mean that the apple is better than those fruits.... that being said.... what is your favorite band?

I love playing video games, listening to music, writing and watching YouTube but I also want to be a musician or an artist. A creator of something. To me, these things are all very important to me. They inspire me and make me happy. But I can't stand this path anymore. It makes me sad. The people that surround me kind of kill my creative aspirations in life. I want to do these great things that I dream of everyday. I just don't know where to start. I don't know where to go with all the people that surround me deterring me of my dreams and creativity. Any advice or suggestions for me? I'd appreciate it. -T
028856.answer: you can always start anywhere, and you will learn something at every moment. so if you absolutely don't know where to start, for a little thrill try starting at what you think is the wrong place to start. the joke will be on you because you will realize it's a great place to start

028857.question: People ask you how to get motivated to do stuff, and you often ask them why they have to do the thing. It seems simple - "just answer the question, and that answer is the thing that motivates you" - but that's not the problem. I know why I need to do it. I know that doing the thing, whatever it is, is the most logically, emotionally, and/or spiritually satifying thing I can do right now, the thing I'll look back on and say "I'm glad I did that thing." It is the best thing to do in every regard, except one: doing the thing will make the right now go from being okay to feeling sucky, and that just sets the rest of my brain in a tizzy, and I try to fight against it but my inner fatass always wins. So, Bill Wurtz, I ask you, how do I garner the mental power to stop my griping and groaning and just do the sucky thing already?
028857.answer: your 4th sentence is your motivation to do the thing. your motivation not to do it is that it is 'sucky.' i actually don't quite understand the task if you've described it as satisfying in so many ways, but then you described it as sucky. the good news is, if you want to do it you can do it, and if you don't want to do it you don't have to. but if you are having trouble deciding, perhaps you could go white water rafting and that might help you think a bit faster

028951.question: I'm trying to write out some music... how would you write out something where you hold out notes, but add notes on top? Like for example if I wanted to play like a Cmaj appergio, playing the C on beat 1, E on 2, G on 3 and C and 4.. but I want the notes held out (so a whole note on C, dotted half note on E, etc)? When I plug a whole note into my software it doesn't let me add any other notes because I think the software thinks that I want to add the notes after 4 beats of the whole note and not while it's ringing out, but maybe I'm writing it wrong. How would you write that out (by hand)?
028951.answer: i can think of 3 ways, none of which are that great. make like 4 parallel universes, and put everybody's notes and rests in, as if there are 4 players sort of borrowing the same staff. if you want to convince a music program to do that, try making different 'voices'? it's a hassle, that's why handwriting is always easier. the next choice would be to tie everything over, and it would look like bigger and bigger stacks. this would be accurate but kind of a mess to read at first glance because it looks like stacked chords. and of course the other way is to just write 4 quarter notes going up and then write something on the top like "sustain" or "please don't let go" or something

029224.question: in your newest video, the first thing that happens is a clock that transforms from a 2D graphic to a 3D object. how did this idea come about?
029224.answer: the extra clocks were a last minute addition, to the song and the video. originally the first thing in the song was just the snare/tom *smack* on beat 4, before the first bar. and the video of the clock dropping. but what i often do with songs, after i finish them, is add a sort of weird and peculiar sound at the very beginning, to help sort of energize things right from the start. so at the last minute, i added the bongo riff. then of course the video needed something to match. so, more clocks, of course, because the first verse starts out about time. after i put in the 2d clocks, it occured to me that the last clock was already near where the video clock would appear, so i made it move to match

029280.question: What's the most common time signature in music after 4/4 and 3/4?
029280.answer: it depends how you write it down. but most music uses repeating patterns of 2, or 3.... 4 would be a repeating pattern of 2. the next available prime number would be 5, which is much much more rare to comprise the main time signature of a song, but it does happen, and there are a handful of famous examples, sometimes with the number 5 in the title

029287.question: whats with all of the owls in the new video?
029287.answer: the first one (actually the later one) was added because something had to be playing the clarinet. the clarinet was added because there was a riff there. the riff was added because it is nice to add little riffs in between lyric lines, when there is a space. the reason the earlier (second to be added) owl is there, is because i was looking out the window, and there was a riff there (added for the same reason as the other riff) which happened to be on the same sound as the other one which i had used an owl for. it made sense for whatever portrays the riff to be in the window. so it seemed useful to use the same thing that would also occur later, because it creates a sense of familiarity when it happens again. also because the first one is upside down and occurs quickly, it presents the viewer with an interesting challenge to notice and identify it

029318.question: I'm having trouble coming up with ideas and bringing them to life. I have ideas but it's like i feel like they're bad ideas and it's gonna suck for myself. And I'm not really that happy with them. I just wish I could come up with an awesome idea that'll push me to do new things that's grand but is also fun to do. I just don't have an idea to act on. I'm just trying to figure things out for myself mentally, like how much work I could handle at the moment, what kind of project I want to work on, and what I want to get out of it, you know? I'm just going back and seeing what I love doing, and what makes me happy and try to work around that. Just trying to do something fulfilling for myself, you know?
029318.answer: i think you should just try making a lot of different ideas, and at least to start, make the projects short enough that they can be finished easily. that way you will get a lot of experience coming up with ideas, and a lot of experience producing them. you can never really sure which idea will be the great one that you are talking about (and not everybody will agree on which one), but if you keep doing them you will soon have no shortage of great things you have done

029378.question: 1.17.18 1:55 am You do it all the time. Talking music theory is talking code.
029378.answer: hold on a second. i feel like i'm going insane here. it seems like every day people ask me to talk about 'music theory' which i think is a misleading term anyway, but i feel like everyone is constantly asking me to talk about it and i feel like i am constantly reminding people that it is all meaningless unless you are considering the way the music ACTUALLY SOUNDS. i feel like i say this over and over again. the question you are originally referring to was someone who was complaining about 'errors on my site' but actually they were talking about what they perceived to be errors in the code, which actually didn't effect the user experience. so i pointed out that i don't think these should be viewed as errors if they don't actually effect the user experience. i want to be clear that i feel EXACTLY the same way about music, and sometimes i feel like a slalom skier trying to dodge all these 'music theory' questions that try to make music out to be something that lives on the page, and sure it's great to be literate but the whole point of it is the way it sounds. so it really drives me crazy that you are blaming me for talking about music code etc when every single time i feel like i have to remind people to return to the way it SOUNDS. so again, let me re-iterate that my views here about music are congruent with the views i said about code, in the other question. i just had to clarify because you are really making me feel insane here and i need to explain this clearly

029403.question: How do you feel when you get comparisons to the existentialist movement? Do you view yourself as an existentialist?
029403.answer: i don't remember that happening i actually think existentialist is a really good word for me, and i sort of hijacked it several years ago to describe a lot of my techniques. i was aware that it was meant for a certain time period, but it just seemed like the word wasn't being used in my area at the time and it felt perfect to describe what i was going through. actually a friend gave it to me, by accident, when i was describing to him my techniques for multi player smash brothers, and balancing the whole board overall rather than going against individual players. he said it sounded like i was getting 'existential' with the game, and i was aware that neither of us really knew where that word came from, but i really like it so i continued using it for a long time. i don't know if anyone else uses the word in this way, the way i use it is sort of like the 'don't play the pieces, play the board' attitude in chess. and it can applied virtually anywhere in life

029449.question: Am I eventually going to have to climb that mountain of learning the whole production-side of making music? When I record I just play into a shit mic that plugs into my computer and I have this interface thing (don't even know what you'd call that type of device) where I can record guitar or keys straight into the computer. I just use the standard recording program that just came with my computer (audacity).. i dont do anything with effects any editing apart from just adjusting the volumes of each track. I love writing and recording music, but the sound quality is always crap. Doesn't really bother me now. But again, I feel like at some point I'm going to have to climb that mountain of learning that side of making music. And it scares me because I don't know where and how to start or when I should just bite the bullet and dive head first into this world.
029449.answer: it depends if you want it to sound any better, but just make small steps. i'm sure there is at least one tiny thing you could do that you already know how to do to make it better. like let's say the drums sound too loud or something. then just turn down the drums a tad. etc, then find another little thing to change. unless you think it sounds ok the way it is, then don't change anything

029453.question: Hey bill. I am kind of a dreamer and I don't quite understand how I developed the mindset I did, being surrounded by so many people who think differently than me, but I'm really happy I did. I just believe more that everybody's special and should do what they want to do in life, regardless of their status and that they have the power to achieve that. But each time I bring this up, my whole family tries so hard to bash into my head that this is the wrong way to approach the world and it really upsets me because I believe that my approach to the world is how one can achieve creation and innovation. Like if we had accepted how things were and never strive to change, us as a human race wouldn't be where we are now. And it saddens me when people around me try soooo hard to force me to think like what they do- don't stand out and accept things the way they are and so much bullshit in my opinion. I look up to a lot of people that inspire me, like you, and s o many o thers, and all the great things that surround me in my life that give me hope that I could push foreword and prove everybody around me wrong. That I can live the life I want, and that I could potentially make it and be like you or my other inspirations and bring more great things to the rest of the world. It's my main motivation in my life at the moment. But it's really hard with so many people surrounding me like this- telling me I shouldn't think this way. I don't agree with settling any less and living someone else's life and wasting what makes me unique and great. It's just difficult to find the time to put my energy into what I want to do with the many responsibilities I have already and With all of these people trying so hard to change me. I know my situation may not seem that bad, but It's kinda driving me crazy. Stressing me out. Sometimes my hope dwindles because of this. I want to breakthrough and prove all of these people wrong, but it's always inevitable that my energy a lways crashes and my hope fades and I fall apart. My question is how do you push through when it seems that the world around you is so against you? What advice do you think would help me Persist?
029453.answer: make in a t.v. show where you must persist despite the world seeming against you

029512.question: I think the lines about the windmills in La de da de da de da de da de day oh is similar to its corresponding lines in the first two verses, "Where did all the good times go" is self explanatory, "Where did all the bad times roll" sound as if you are wondering where the bad times came from, and "when did all the windmills start to turn so slow" is like a metaphor about how the wind has stopped, like the good times stopping. At least that's my take on that line. You said it just fits but I think it actually makes sense.
029512.answer: they way i heard it, it could actually mean 2 things. it could mean the windmills were previously going fast and they recently started going slow. or it could mean that they were previously not moving, and they recently started turning (slow). i can also tell you that as i was writing the choruses, thinking of various swap lines for "where did all the good times go" .. my brain kept feeding me "when" .. as in La de da de "when did all the ? ? ?" but nothing seemed to fit. the windmill line was a perfect solution for this because it allows me to use "when", but because the line starts a little earlier it also allows me to land on "wind" at the same time that "when" would have been if the line were the normal length

'got to know' was newly written except for the title. 'i love you' was written in 2009/2012, and the instruments were recorded in 2015, but then newly underwent a massive lyric swap in 2017. california was written in 2011/2013, and recorded in 2017. history of the entire world was written in summer/fall of 2016 and recorded immediately after. alphabet shuffle was partially written in 2012, 2014, and 2016. old mcdonald was written in 2014. snail time was newly written. what is love was newly written. i'm not sure if that answers your question

029784.question: ok so here's a fun fact, and some fun information you would like to know about having a discord server. now that you have one, you can make it function however you like. you can have multiple conversation channels for different types of conversation, (maybe a separate channel for the mods, a separate channel for talking about sensitive topics, a separate channel for pasting the rules of the chat, to explain to the people how each channel is designed to be used, etc.) . also you can have voice channels, where people can talk to each other. you can have as many as you like, and call them whatever you want. you can also put them in any order. another fun thing about discord is "roles", you can give create little tags which can allow the person access to whatever channels you set it to, and you can make their name whatever color you want. you can set roles that can change other roles, create channels, move channels, all sorts of shenanigans you can give people a ccess to or not. finally, to open it up to the public, simply post an invite link somewhere on your webpage, or somewhere like on your twitter. you can set these invite links to expire, or not. it's all up to you. that's a discord crash course, i hope it made sense, if there are any questions, just let me know and i'll get back to you somehow!

029829.question: Hey bill, i really struggle writing bridges to my songs. All the transitions I make seem either way too boring or too out of place, any advice?
029829.answer: go back to the last point where everything still works. that is called the 'split point.' keep considering every different kind of possibility for what happens after the split point. some ideas you may not have considered: ending the song. repeating something. doing something entirely new. one of these options, people often forget. another interesting trick after the 2nd chorus is launching into the next thing slightly earlier than the end of the 2nd chorus. keep returning to the absolute split point (that's the point before which you are sure everything is totally good) and just keep trying things and be open to anything including ending it. and do timed run-throughs, and to clear your mind each time first, go touch the door handle while the metronome is running and return to the writing station and do the run-through

029860.question: 1.22.18 10:46 pm according to google maps that takes 74 hours to walk (without a ferry). how did you accomplish that, where did you sleep, what did you bring?
029860.answer: according to google maps, the route i took is actually 13 and a half hours, and i did it over 2 days. and i also took a slight detour. on the first day, i went from bensonhurst to williamsburg (u know the corner of bedford ave and 7th west hipster st) and then i basically went straight out metropolitan to jamaica. from jamaica i took the train back to bensonhurst. then the next day i took the train back to jamaica, and picked up where i left off. then i walked all the way to the edge of suffolk county. it was residential and the sidewalks were disappearing, and my phone went dead, but there was someone out front of their house who confirmed that yes i had reached the edge of suffolk county, and they also told me how to get to the train. that would have been the huntington lirr station
